metadata.titleEn: Dataset of urban land and urbanization index on the Tibetan Plateau (2018, 2019)
metadata.description: The dataset of urban land and urbanization index on the Tibetan Plateau mainly includes the spatial distribution data of all urban land on the Tibetan Plateau (2019) and urbanization index of different scales (2018). The dataset of urban land was obtained by the visual interpretation of Google Earth images (2019), and the residential place and residential area data of "1:250000 national basic geographic database - 2015 edition". The dataset of urbanization index was based on the composite night light index (CNLI) at the regional, provincial, watershed, prefecture, and county scales calculated from the night light data of Luojia-1. Our dataset will support the study of optimizing the ecological security barrier system in the key urbanization areas of the Tibetan Plateau
metadata.instructions:
Filename: the dataset of urban land on the Tibetan Plateau is stored in Shp format, and the dataset of urbanization index on the Tibetan Plateau is stored in Excel format. The dataset of urban land on the Tibetan Plateau is named as Built-upArea_ TP_ 2019。 Built-upArea represents the built-up area, TP represents Tibetan Plateau, and 2019 represents the year. The dataset of urbanization index on the Tibetan Plateau is named CNLI_ LJ1-01_ TP-2018, CNLI stands for the composite light index, LJ1-01 stands for the luojia-1 satellite, TP stands for the Tibetan Plateau, and 2018 represents the year.
Data reading method: the dataset of urban land on the Tibetan Plateau can be opened by ArcGIS, and the dataset of urbanization index can be opened by Excel.

literatureList.titleEn: Quantifying urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau with high-resolution nighttime light data
literatureList.referenceEn: Wang, Y.H., Liu Z.F., He C.Y., Xia P., Liu, Z.W, Liu, H.M. (2020). Quantifying urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau with high-resolution nighttime light data. Geography and Sustainability, 1(3), 233-244.

placeKeywordList.keywordEn: Key urbanized area of Qinghai-Tibet Plateau

fundVOList.titleEn: Second Tibetan Plateau Scientific Expedition and Research Programme (STEP)

projectList.titleEn: National Tibetan Plateau / Third Pole Environment Data Center

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP) is known as the “Roof of the World,” “Asian Water Tower,” and “Earth’s Third Pole,” which is an important ecological security barrier and a special cultural protection site in China, as well as a region affecting global sustainable development. Driven by the “development of western regions,” “new-type urbanization planning,” and the “Belt and Road initiative,” the TP is undergoing rapid socioeconomic development. Researchers have carried out several studies on the TP’s urbanization level at different scales. Nighttime light (NTL) data provide an effective way to quantify the TP’s urbanization level. Traditional NTL data from the Defense Meteorological Satellite Program-Operational Linescan System (DMSP-OLS) and Suomi National Polar-Orbiting Partnership-Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (NPP-VIIRS) reflect city lights as well as low-intensity lights from small human settlements, traffic flows, and can clearly distinguish the lights from rural backgrounds. Luojia 1-01 (LJ1-01) high-resolution NTL data provides a new source for quantifying the urbanization level on the TP because it compensates for the deficiencies of DMSP-OLS and NPP-VIIRS data.
research objective: This study aims to quantify the urbanization level on the TP in 2018 with Luojia1-01 (LJ1-01) high-resolution nighttime light (NTL) data. The objective of this study is to quantify spatial patterns of urbanization level on the TP using LJ1-01 NTL data.
challenges: However, these socioeconomic data lack comparability and are incomplete at the county level on the TP. Therefore, there remains a lack of county-level assessment and in-depth understanding of urbanization levels and spatial patterns of the TP.
methods: The LJ1-01 NTL data used to calculate the urbanization level were obtained from the Luojia1-01 nighttime light map of China. We used the CNLI proposed by Zhuo et al. (2003) to measure the TP’s urbanization level. Based on the above equations, we calculated the TP’s CNLI at the basin, prefecture, and county levels.
dataset: The LJ1-01 NTL data used to calculate the urbanization level were obtained from the Luojia1-01 nighttime light map of China. The NPP-VIIRS data used for comparison with the LJ1-01 NTL data were downloaded from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/National Center for Environmental Information (NOAA/NGDC). Easygo data, with a spatial resolution of 25 m, were used to reflect the spatial distribution of the region’s population. The built-up area data used to calculate the comprehensive urbanization level index were extracted from the global land cover data in 2017 in the FROM-GCL10 dataset, with a spatial resolution of 10 m and an overall accuracy of 72.8%. Digital elevation model (DEM) data used to analyze the influencing factors of the spatial pattern of urbanization level were obtained from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM). The soil data were extracted from the soil map-based Harmonized World Soil Database (v1.2) of the National TP Data Center, with a spatial resolution of 1 km. The meteorological observation data were derived from the China Meteorological Data Service Centre, including the mean annual temperature, precipitation, wind speed, relative humidity, and sunshine hours data for 839 meteorological sites in China. Transportation data were downloaded from OpenStreetMap.
findings: The results showed that the TP had a low overall urbanization level with a large internal difference. The urbanization level in the northeast, southeast, and south of the TP was relatively high, forming three hotspots centered in Xining City, Lhasa City, and Shangri-La City, while the urbanization level in the central and western regions was relatively low. The analysis of influencing factors, based on the random forest model, showed that transportation and topography were the main factors affecting the TP’s spatial patterns of urbanization level.

Verification.Question: Is the use of Luojia1-01 nighttime light data an appropriate method for quantifying urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Is the Compound Night Light Index (CNLI) a reliable indicator for assessing urbanization levels across different scales on the Tibetan Plateau?

Disjunctive.Question: Are nighttime light data more effectively captured using LJ1-01, DMSP-OLS, or NPP-VIIRS for urbanization studies on the Tibetan Plateau?

Concept Completion.Question: Where can potential datasets for urbanization research on the Tibetan Plateau be sourced?
Concept Completion.Answer: Luojia1-01 nighttime light map of China, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/National Center for Environmental Information, Easygo, FROM-GCL10 dataset, Shuttle Radar Topography Mission, Harmonized World Soil Database, China Meteorological Data Service Centre, OpenStreetMap

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges are associated with assessing urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau using existing datasets?
Concept Completion.Answer: lack of comparability and incompleteness of socioeconomic data

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to quantify urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used is the utilization of Luojia1-01 (LJ1-01) high-resolution nighttime light (NTL) data to calculate the urbanization level on the Tibetan Plateau. This method involves using the Luojia1-01 nighttime light map of China and calculating the Compound Night Light Index (CNLI) at various scales to measure urbanization levels.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when assessing urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau using socioeconomic data?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced is the lack of comparability and incompleteness of socioeconomic data at the county level on the Tibetan Plateau, which hampers a comprehensive assessment and understanding of the urbanization levels and spatial patterns at this level.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of the Compound Night Light Index (CNLI) used to measure urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: nighttime light data, Luojia1-01, NPP-VIIRS, quantify urbanization levels, basin level, prefecture level, county level

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of the Luojia1-01 high-resolution nighttime light data that make it suitable for urbanization studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: detailed information on city lights, low-intensity lights from small human settlements, low-intensity lights from traffic flows

Feature Specification.Question: What are the primary factors affecting the spatial patterns of urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the Easygo data used to reflect the spatial distribution of the region’s population?
How many meteorological sites provided data for analyzing the mean annual temperature and other climate factors in China?

Definition.Question: What is the 'Compound Night Light Index (CNLI)' in the context of urbanization studies on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The Compound Night Light Index (CNLI) is a metric used to measure the urbanization level on the Tibetan Plateau, utilizing nighttime light data from sources such as the Luojia1-01 satellite. It provides an assessment of the urbanization level at various spatial scales including basin, prefecture, and county levels.

Definition.Question: What are 'Easygo data' in the context of analyzing population distribution on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Easygo data, with a spatial resolution of 25 meters, is used to reflect the spatial distribution of the population in the Tibetan Plateau region. This dataset helps in understanding patterns of human settlement and contributes to the calculation of urbanization levels.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using Luojia1-01 high-resolution nighttime light data compare to traditional socioeconomic data in assessing urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The Luojia1-01 high-resolution nighttime light data provide a more comprehensive and comparable method for assessing urbanization levels, as traditional socioeconomic data often lack comparability and completeness, especially at the county level on the Tibetan Plateau.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the spatial resolutions of the LJ1-01 nighttime light map and the FROM-GCL10 dataset differ in their effectiveness for urbanization level quantification on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The LJ1-01 nighttime light map provides high-resolution data that effectively captures nighttime lights, while the FROM-GCL10 dataset, with a spatial resolution of 10 m, offers detailed built-up area data. Both contribute to different aspects of urbanization quantification but differ in spatial resolution and specific focus areas.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities in using NPP-VIIRS data versus LJ1-01 nighttime light data for measuring urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Both NPP-VIIRS and LJ1-01 provide nighttime light data for urbanization measurement, but LJ1-01 offers higher resolution, which compensates for deficiencies in the NPP-VIIRS data, especially in distinguishing low-intensity lights from small human settlements and traffic flows.

Interpretation.Question: How can nighttime light data be utilized to infer the spatial patterns of urbanization levels in regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Nighttime light data, such as the Luojia1-01 high-resolution nighttime light data, can be used to quantify urbanization levels by reflecting city lights and low-intensity lights from human settlements. This data compensates for deficiencies in traditional datasets and helps measure urbanization levels at various scales, such as basin, prefecture, and county levels.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are typically faced when collecting socioeconomic data for assessing urbanization levels at the county level on the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the lack of comparability and completeness of socioeconomic data at the county level on the Tibetan Plateau. This presents difficulties in conducting in-depth assessments and understanding the spatial patterns of urbanization in the region.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the key factors influencing the spatial patterns of urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau from the observed data?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of a random forest model indicated that transportation and topography are the main factors affecting the spatial patterns of urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau. The analysis showed significant regional differences, with more urbanized areas in the northeast, southeast, and south forming hotspots around Xining City, Lhasa City, and Shangri-La City.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors influence the choice of nighttime light data sources, such as LJ1-01, for quantifying urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Nighttime light data sources like LJ1-01 are chosen to quantify urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau because they compensate for the deficiencies of other traditional NTL data, such as DMSP-OLS and NPP-VIIRS, by providing high-resolution data that can distinguish city lights and low-intensity lights from small human settlements and traffic flows.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for utilizing meteorological and transportation data in analyzing the spatial patterns of urbanization on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Meteorological and transportation data are utilized in analyzing the spatial patterns of urbanization on the Tibetan Plateau because they are key factors influencing these patterns. The analysis using a random forest model showed that transportation and topography significantly affect the urbanization levels and their spatial distribution across the plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What potential outcomes could arise from using compound night light indices in urbanization studies across different scales, such as county and province levels?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using compound night light indices in urbanization studies across different scales could result in more detailed and comparable assessments of urbanization levels, allowing for the identification of spatial patterns and the evaluation of development disparities across the Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind using high-resolution nighttime light (NTL) data to quantify urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to quantify the spatial patterns of urbanization level on the Tibetan Plateau using Luojia1-01 (LJ1-01) high-resolution NTL data, as it compensates for the deficiencies of traditional NTL data and provides an effective way to measure urbanization levels on the plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to assess the urbanization levels at different scales on the Tibetan Plateau using CNLI and other datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to provide a comprehensive assessment of urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau at different scales, such as basin, prefecture, and county levels, to overcome the lack of comparability and completeness in traditional socioeconomic data and enhance understanding of spatial patterns and urbanization impacts.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the integration of multiple data sources like DEM, soil data, and transportation data in examining urbanization patterns on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to analyze influencing factors such as transportation and topography on the spatial patterns of urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau, providing a more nuanced understanding of the region's urbanization dynamics and supporting ecological and urban planning initiatives.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps to utilize nighttime light data for assessing urbanization levels in a given region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To utilize nighttime light data for assessing urbanization levels, the first step involves obtaining high-resolution nighttime light data, such as from Luojia1-01. The Compound Night Light Index (CNLI) is then calculated to quantify the urbanization level at different scales, such as basin, prefecture, and county levels. Additionally, comparisons with other datasets like NPP-VIIRS can be performed to validate findings.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can transportation and topography data be integrated into the analysis of urbanization spatial patterns?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Transportation data can be downloaded from sources like OpenStreetMap and topography data can be obtained from digital elevation models such as the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM). These datasets are then analyzed using models like the random forest model to understand their influence on the spatial patterns of urbanization levels.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to ensure the accuracy of population distribution data in urbanization studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Population distribution data can be reflected using high-resolution spatial datasets such as Easygo data, which has a spatial resolution of 25 m. Accuracy is ensured by using comprehensive datasets like the FROM-GCL10 global land cover data, which provides built-up area data and has an overall accuracy of 72.8%.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the accurate assessment of urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of Luojia1-01 high-resolution nighttime light data enables accurate assessment of urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau. This is complemented by the integration of NPP-VIIRS data for comparison and validation, as well as the use of Easygo data to reflect population distribution.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of diverse datasets enhance the understanding of urbanization patterns on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of datasets such as Luojia1-01 nighttime light data, NPP-VIIRS data, global land cover data, digital elevation models, and soil and meteorological data enhances the understanding of urbanization patterns by providing a comprehensive view of spatial distribution, influencing factors like transportation and topography, and environmental conditions.

Enablement.Question: What factors enable the identification of key influences on the spatial patterns of urbanization in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The identification of key influences on spatial patterns of urbanization in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau is enabled by the use of random forest models to analyze factors such as transportation networks and topography, which are derived from datasets including OpenStreetMap and Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in achieving comparability and completeness of socioeconomic data at the county level on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The socioeconomic data lack comparability and completeness at the county level on the TP, which hinders a thorough assessment and understanding of urbanization levels and spatial patterns.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for using Luojia1-01 high-resolution nighttime light data instead of traditional nighttime light datasets in assessing urbanization on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Luojia1-01 high-resolution nighttime light data provides a new source for quantifying the urbanization level on the TP because it compensates for the deficiencies of traditional DMSP-OLS and NPP-VIIRS data, which also reflect city lights but can include low-intensity lights from small human settlements and traffic flows.

Expectation.Question: What are the expectations for identifying the main factors affecting the spatial patterns of urbanization level on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The analysis, based on a random forest model, showed that transportation and topography were the main factors affecting the TP’s spatial patterns of urbanization level.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using high-resolution nighttime light data to quantify urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: High-resolution nighttime light data, such as that from Luojia1-01, are considered effective for quantifying urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau because they provide a detailed view of city lights and low-intensity lights from smaller settlements, which are difficult to capture with traditional methods. This data compensates for the deficiencies found in older datasets like DMSP-OLS and NPP-VIIRS, offering a more accurate representation of the spatial patterns of urbanization.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges and limitations in collecting socioeconomic data to assess urbanization levels at the county level on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: A significant challenge in collecting socioeconomic data for assessing urbanization levels at the county level on the Tibetan Plateau is the lack of comparability and completeness of the data. This incomplete data hinders a comprehensive assessment and understanding of urbanization levels and spatial patterns at the county level, making it difficult to draw detailed conclusions across different regions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods could accurately reflect the urbanization level across different scales on the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: The use of Luojia 1-01 high-resolution nighttime light data provides an effective means to quantify the urbanization level across different scales on the Tibetan Plateau. This method compensates for deficiencies in previous data sources like DMSP-OLS and NPP-VIIRS by capturing both city lights and low-intensity lights from smaller settlements and traffic, allowing for a nuanced assessment of urbanization.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about which datasets are essential for assessing the urbanization level on the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Key datasets for assessing urbanization on the Tibetan Plateau include Luojia 1-01 nighttime light data for high-resolution urbanization quantification, NPP-VIIRS data for comparison, Easygo data for population distribution, built-up area data from FROM-GCL10 for comprehensive urbanization index calculation, and additional datasets like DEM from SRTM and soil data from the Harmonized World Soil Database for spatial pattern analysis.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges faced in collecting comprehensive socioeconomic data on the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: A significant challenge in collecting socioeconomic data on the Tibetan Plateau is the lack of comparability and incompleteness at the county level, which hinders thorough county-level assessments and a deep understanding of urbanization patterns. Efforts to quantify urbanization have to address these disparities in data availability and quality.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced when using high-resolution nighttime light data to quantify urbanization levels on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the lack of comparability and incomplete socioeconomic data at the county level on the Tibetan Plateau, which makes it difficult to conduct a comprehensive county-level assessment and gain an in-depth understanding of urbanization levels and spatial patterns.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential data sources for enhancing the spatial resolution of urbanization level indicators on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential data sources for enhancing the spatial resolution of urbanization level indicators include the Luojia1-01 nighttime light map of China for high-resolution NTL data, Easygo data for population distribution with a spatial resolution of 25 m, and FROM-GCL10 dataset for built-up area data with a spatial resolution of 10 m.
